CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial
JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He is an attorney .

CARDINAL . The applicant was suspected of aiding and abetting aggravated embezzlement . He was first questioned by the police on DATE . He was subsequently questioned again in connection with CARDINAL other similar offences .

CARDINAL . On DATE the public prosecutor brought charges against him and another defendant , R , in the GPE ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätten ) . The court held its first session on DATE . In the course of the proceedings , the court was presented with written evidence , including CARDINAL documents submitted by the applicant . It also received testimony from both defendants and CARDINAL witnesses , CARDINAL of whom were called by the applicant . The evidence included a written statement and the oral testimony of ORG . On DATE the court gave its judgment . It found that on DATE the applicant had , as a receiver of a bankrupt ’s estate , unlawfully transferred a substantial sum of money from the estate ’s bank account to the account of his own law firm . The court also found that , on the same date , he had aided and abetted his associate R in the commission of CARDINAL similar offences . The court convicted the applicant of aggravated embezzlement and CARDINAL counts of aiding and abetting aggravated embezzlement and sentenced him to a suspended term of DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . R was found guilty of having made unlawful money transfers on several separate occasions DATE and DATE . He was convicted of CARDINAL counts of aggravated embezzlement , as well as aiding and abetting the applicant ’s aggravated embezzlement .

CARDINAL . The applicant , R , and the prosecutor all appealed against the judgment to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätten ) . At the applicant ’s request , the court had extended by DATE the time - limit for lodging his appeal . In his letter of appeal , lodged on DATE , the applicant claimed that he had only transferred funds to which he believed he was entitled as a retainer and that he had , therefore , lacked criminal intent . He made similar claims in connection with the CARDINAL counts of aiding and abetting R ’s offences . He also referred , inter alia , to the written statement of ORG , in which the latter had considered it possible that the applicant had , in fact , lacked criminal intent in regard to the alleged embezzlement . On DATE ORG held an oral hearing . By its judgment of CARDINAL DATE it upheld the applicant ’s conviction but changed his sentence to DATE and QUANTITY months’ unconditional imprisonment . In its reasons the court had regard , inter alia , to ORG testimony . The ORG had noted , inter alia , that at the time of drawing up his written statement he had not had all the information about the applicant ’s actions in the matter or , at least , had not paid attention to it . He had also testified that the receiver of a bankrupt ’s estate did not have a right to withdraw money from the estate ’s account without consent .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) refused leave to appeal .
CARDINAL . LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflagen ; as amended by LAW . CARDINAL/CARDINAL which took effect on DATE ) reads :
“ In addition to what is provided above in section CARDINAL , grounds for mitigating the sentence that are also to be taken into consideration are
( CARDINAL ) a considerably long period that has passed since the commission of the offence ;
if the punishment that accords with established practice would for these reasons lead to an unreasonable or exceptionally detrimental result . ”

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE ( ORG CARDINAL ) , ORG noted that , although there were no legal provisions justifying the dismissal of a criminal charge due to unreasonably long proceedings , such a dismissal or declaring a case inadmissible might in some exceptional circumstances , for example if their duration ruled out a good defence , be the only effective remedy satisfying the requirements of LAW . That was , however , not the case here . In considering whether there were grounds for applying LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL of LAW , ORG held that it had to be decided in PERSON whether the duration of the proceedings ( here over DATE ) had been unreasonable . It concluded that in this case there were no grounds not to impose a sentence or to mitigate the sentence owing to the duration of the proceedings .
